editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: PSALMA DHAIBHIDH A NMEADRACHD. Do reír an phriomh-chanamain. Le MA: RAIBEARD KIRK, Miniſdir SHOIGEIL CHRIOSD aig BALBHUIDIER. Maille re Ughdarras.
div.q: A bfuil neach gu dubhach inar meaſg? deanadh ſé urnaidh. Abfuil neach ar bioth ſubhach? Sinnadh é Sailm. Ebiſd: Sheum: Caibid. 5. Rann. 13.
div.p: Ar a ngcur a ngeló a nDún-Edin le M. Sémus Kniblo, Ioſua van Solingen agus Seón Colmar, 1684.

div.head: The Priviledge.
div.p: FORASMƲCH as there being an addreſse made to the Lords of his Majeſties privy Councill, by Mr Robert Kirk miniſter at Balqwhidder, Bearing, that the petitioner hath been at great paines, diligence, and exactneſs in tranſlating the Pſalmes of David in Scottiſh-Iriſh meeter, which hath hitherto been indeavoured by many, but never till now brought to perfection. And in regaird the ſaid tranſlation, is approven by ſome of the Lords of the Clergy, and ſome reverend Miniſters who beſt underſtand the Iriſh-Language, as their approbation more fully beares: Humbly Supplicating, That the Councill would give order for printing the ſaid tranſlation, and diſcharge all others from doing the ſame, during ſuch ſpace as the Councill ſhould think fit. The ſaids Lords having conſidered the foreſaid addreſſe, with a certificat under the hands of ſeverall of the clergy, of the exactnes of the work of the ſaid tranſlation of the Pſalmes into Scotiſh-Iriſh me • ter, and of the uſefulnes of it for ſuch as do not underſtand the Engliſh tranſlation; Do Approve of the petitioners great care and paines: and of the ſaid work done by him in perfecting the ſaid tranſlation; And allow the ſame to be printed. And give and Grant to the petitioner, his aires and aſſigneies, the ſole power and priviledge of printing thereof: And Diſcharge all others ſo to do, for the ſpace of eleven years after the date hereof, under the pain of confiſcation of the ſame to the Petitioner and his foreſaids uſe, and being furder puniſhed as the councill ſhall find cauſe. Extr. by me

div.head: To the Potent and Renoun'd, Lord JOHN MURRAY, Marqueſs of ATHOLE, Earl of Tullibardin, Viſcount of Balquidder, Lord Murray and Balveny, Lord Keeper of his Majeſty Privy Seal, &c.
div.p: THE Matter of this Book, Moſt noble Marqueſs, ſounded on inſpir'd Writings, needs no Defence, but a Metrical Tranſlation of ſo Divine and rapturous a Subject, into a language, not ſo much cultivate and poliſht with Learning, Oratory, and Divine poeſy as need were; and done by ſuch as attain'd not the tongue without indefatigable induſtry, doth require Religious, Equitable and Generous perſons to own it.

Your Noble ſelf is patron of the place where the Tranſlator officiats as a Presbyter. You are now of the greateſt Command among thoſe that make uſe of this Scotiſh-Iriſh Language on either ſyde of the Grampian Mountains. Your Lordſhip, hath ever been of undoubted courage, and loyalty for the King; and ſtill alongſt inflexible to the perſuaſions or Threats of frozen Newtraliſts or Flaming incen diaries in Church or State. Your ſolid Moderation (a monument and copy for ſucceeding Ages) in Diſputable caſes of Church-Government and State policy, with a conſtant regard to upright juſtice, and piety, hath by the providence of Heaven, occaſion'd your Lordſhips ſtanding in what Reelings and Revolutions have been: which was much furthered by your ſo Chriſtian and ſagacious obſervance of our Saviours injunction anent the chief ſeats; In being ever the Higher the Humbler. Were this public acknowledgment then to be accounted of, it could no where be ſo aptly plac'd, & to none more worthily aſcrib'd then to your Noble ſel • , of ſuch merit in general, Beſides my particular Benefactor.

The Language being Vehicl of the more ſubſtantial part, I endeavour'd here what was native and proper, but clean and plain for all capacities, ſhunning
as much as I could, tedious, tumultuous and disjoynted phraſes. And tho I have alſo ſ • ript ſome words of their ſuperfluous and •••• ul • tory letters, reſerving the poſſeſſive, as the ſeveral Iriſh Grammers come to my hands, do allow; Yet no humane work can pretend to be ſo abſolute s to be beyond all Correction. Notwithſtanding, My Lord, it may be not unworthy the pains in every Age to contribute a mite or two at leaſt to the Churches Corban, For aſſiſting of our Sagacious Scot • ſh Iriſh people in their publick or private Devotions; ſpeci • lly ſeing experience tells us that this their matern • l Tongue either in Ireland or Scotland, is not eaſily aboliſht by the contiguity and commixture of another language: which no doubt is well underſtood by the preſent worthy and Laborious Tranſlators of the H. Bible in Iriſh.

In reference to ſuch pious and laudable interpriſes your Lordſhip is lookt upon as ane Ebed-melech, to defend and encourage the Authors, that they be not diſmounted, and made to ſtagger from their poſt and province, becauſe of the tang of Atheiſm ſo much prevailing, the forlorn art of ridiculing with all things, and many mens utter diſdaining of what is not ſhapt in their own mould. For the ſpiderweb of ſuch polluted vanities, pompous and ultramundane fancy's, in perſons either couragiouſly wicked, politickly profane, or monſtruouſly invidious. is too thin, not to be diſcover'd by your Lordſhip, as it is by all who love what is ſober, and do not follow the guiſe of living in a deſperate Autonomy, flouting at all that's ſerious, adoring only the Idol they form to themſelv's, and not conſidering the end. Among others that thus preſume on your Lordſhips patrociny and candid acceptance, is one who implores the Divine Conduct in this World, and Happineſs in the next, to your Honurable Self and all the branches of your Noble ſtem, and is ſtill determin'd.

closer.signed: To ſerve your Lordſhip in all the Offices of Honour and Duty M. R. Kirk.

div.head: Don' LEAGHCHORA, Sith & Slainte.
div.p: ATaid na Pſalma taitneamhach, tarbhach: • eag nach mion-fhlaitheas lán dainglibh, Cill fhonnmhar le ceól naomhtha. Mur abholghort Eden, líonta do chrannuibh brioghmh • ire na • eatha, & do lu • bhennibh jocſ • lainteamhail, amhleidh an leabhar Pſalm ſo Dhaibhioth, ata na liagh • i • ar uile anſhocair na nanma. Ata an ſaoghal & gach beó-chreatuir da bfuil ann, na chlarſigh: An du ne, ſe is Clairſeoir & duanaire, chum moladh an mor-Dhia mirbhuileach do ſh • inm; & ata Daibhidh do ghná mar fhear don chuideachd bhias marſo ag caoin-chaint gu ceólmhar ma nard. Rí.

Achd cheana, chum nach tuiſleochadh tintiun ag leaghadh an 109. Salm, no codcha da leitheid eile, Tuig nach câineadh no aoire na ndaoine is ciall ſpioradalta dhoibh ſúd, achd guidheacha amháin anaghaidh eaſcairde na nanma, bhias dar broſnughadh & dar breugnughadh chum ladh De chur a neimh-ſhuim. Níor ghabh fós achd an ai • bfhioſach, Faighidheacht ar Judais no a choſmhul eile, a riocht guidheacha coitchionda. • s ceaduighteach ge ta, a jarraidh m • r athchoinnidh ar Dhia, Gan mirunn & mi-ghniomh luchd uilc a leigmhail ar bhuil, anadhaidh na Heagluiſi & na ngcreidmheacha: & taire ſin a fhuraileadh, Smachd ſeimh aimſ • ordha theachd ar an trù, da cheartughadh, & los gabhail roimh a ſgrioſadh ſiorraidh; amhuil do ni deagh-Jeremias air fein C. 10. R. 24. Is dual fadheoigh, do na Firenibh na hinnil ciuil ata ainmnight fna
ſalmoibh, a thuigſinn ar gleus bhruideadh neamhdha, do chumhachdaibh ſpioradadha an anam, chum Dia do ghlorughadh.

Do chuir ſinn an tſaothairſe an uaim, a mbriathraibh ſcagtha, athehumair; ar chomhbeag corrachus is a bfeidir linn. Gabhſa do tuaiſle phrionnſamhail, mar dheagh-fhlaith ghrianda, leithſgeul ar nuireaſbhuidh, gan bheith codarſna, contrardha. Ni caire ar neach Dia dhonorughadh mur is fearr thig leis. Do ghabhas mar chongnamh don obairſi, dioghlom ughdairidh an uile cháil, ar ſheannós, phriomhchreideamh & eachdardha na n • aoidheal, ſgriobhta & cló-bhuailte: achd gu bareula juil & ſoluis dhamb, bri • h na nSalm fein. Anois maſeadh a Chomharbadha ro chaomh, ata mar phlaneidi dhealroidh ag ſdiurughadh na ngcorp jochdardha gan mhonmar, is deaghmhaiſe dhaoibh an tſaothairſe a ſgrudadh & a ghnathughadh gu neimhf • iat, gan ghuth ar bheiginmhe & neimhnitheachd an • tſaothairigh. Grioſam oraibhſe a Ʋaiſle, & a Thuatha charthanacha araon, gan bheith mur thacharain ar lua drean a nunn & a nall go ſbailpe breigi; achd le gcroidbihh daingne, doſgartha, deagh-fhreumhaighte, druididh re Firinn, Ceart, & Ceannſachd, mar fhuraileas na pſalma: Ata clu & tarbha a nſdriocadh don choir; call & maſla, a ntuitim le heugcoir.

Achd ein ni maith cho bhi on dreim
11. O tiocfaidh, chlann, is eiſdidh riom:
12. Cia ghraidheas laith, 'ſler baill bhi beo
1 • . O mheabhail coimhed glan do bheul,
14. Olc ſeachain agus dean an maith,
16. Ta adhaidh ar luchd uilc a chlaoi,
17. Ghlaodh Firenidh ré Dia, is chual,
18. 'Sdlu Dia do luchd a chroidh briſt',
achd Dia bheir aſt' gu ler.
aon, ni bfuil briſt, a Dhé.
21. Achd marbhaidh olcmhas fein an daoi:
ar aon diobh cho tig claoi.
DHIA tagair féin re luchd mo ſtribh:
cuir trod air luchd mo chath.
2. Glac fein do thargaid is do ſgia,
3. Dhia, nochd do lann, an echlidh druid
Re manam abair, Dhe, mar ſo,
4. Trom-náir is maſladh gu raibh dhoibh
5. Iad ruaigeadh aingeal Dé, is bid
6. Dorch, ſleamhoin ſós gu raibh an júl,
7. Oir dfholigh ſiad gan adhbhar dhamh
Fior-uamh do chlaoich iad gan chion-fath,
8. Nois thigeadh doghruinn air gan fhios,
Sa nſgrioſadh chuimir é do chách
10. Is deir mo chnamhan uil', a Dhe,
An tainnis is a mbochd on tí
11. Luchd fiaghnais bhreig a deirigh riom,
is chuir ſiad as mo leth
12. Ole dhiol ſiad riom an craic mhaith
13. Achd mis, ghabh umam culuidh bhrôin
tra 'ſ rinn doibh ſud gach ti:
Le troſgadh dumhluigh mi me féin,
14. Mar gu budh caraid é, no brathair
Mar neach bhiodh caoineadh fós a mhathar
15. Achd ann mo thuiſleadh, is am' theinn
Do chruinnighdear iad féin re cheil:
Gan fhios am adhaidh, thionoil iad,
is réub ſiad me gan tamh.
16. Luchd ſcalloid chealgach fos bheith ann,
Chiond bhi re ſugra, gheibheadh biagh:
17. Cia fhad do chi tu ſo a Dhé?
Mo ſheircin ſaor o leoghnaibh garg
18. Dhuit bheir me buidheachas gu hait
Is meaſg an tſluaigh 'ta lionmhar mor
ard mhol • am thu gu ré.
19. Sluagh, naimhdeoil dhamh gan adhbhar chneaſd
Don dréim thug fuadh dhamh fos gan chuis,
20. Ar ſiothchaimh oir ni bſuil a • gcaint',
Do dhaoinibh ſamhach ſeimh na tír,
21. Am adhaidh dfhoſguil ſiad a mbeul
Ag radh, Aha, aha, gan cheiſt
22. Dhia, chunnaic thu, na bi ad' thoſd;
23. Tog ort, is moſguil chum mo cheart:
a mchúis a Dhia, bi leam:
24. A reir do cheartais, orm dean breath:
25. Nar abradh ſiad na ngcroidh ah, ah,
an neith budh mhaith linn, choim:
Ni mó leig dhoibh a radh a mfeaſt,
Síos ſhluig ſinn é gan ſtad.
26. Biodh orra náir' is tairngear iad
An dreím da ngnáth bhi ait ma mphein,
Líon dheighreas ard a maghaidh fein,
Gu ſoillier abradh iad do ghna,
28. Ma d'cheartais labhraidh tric mo theangc,
DEIR eaſaontas a ndaoi a mchroidh
2. Oir ni ſé brional breíg dho fein,
Do ſguir ſé fos o dheanamh maith,
is leig ſé dhe bhith glic.
A nſlighe nach bfuil maith do neach,
don ole nior ghabh ſe grain.
6. Do cheartas mar na beannaird ghlan,
Ta muinighin, fuidh ſgail do ſgé,
bhridh ſin, aig clann na ndaoin.
8. Bid ſáſight Dhé, le ſaill do theach,
digh bheir tu dhoibh gu lór.
9. Oir tobar glan na beath' ta lear,
10. Do mhuirne buanaigh chaoich don' dreim
don' druing bhi ceart a ngcroidh.
11. Na leig do chois an ardan bhuirb
Do leagadh iad: is fos ni 'ſmo:
NA las a ncampar re luchd uilc,
2. Oir buaintear iad gu lua mar fheur,
3. Earb ris an Tighearn', is dean maith,
Is gheibh do riachdas-leas gan cheiſt,
4. Gabh tlachd dhuit fein a nDia na ngras,
is bheir dhuit runn do chroidh.
5. Earb ris do chuis, is bheir gu crich:
6. Is bheir ſe mach do chóir 'ſdo cheart
Do chomhthrom fos mar mheadhon laoi
7. Gabh clos gu ſamhach ann a nDia;
Is na gabh formad ris an ti
Na gluais fa 'nti do bheir gu buil
8. Na bi gad' chreinm fein re holc:
9. Oir drochdhaoin' leanas olc do ghna
Achd lion ga bfuil an ſul re Dia
10. Oir feith re ſealan bhig, 'ſcho bhl
Bheir tu a áit' fanear gu geur
11. Achd daoine ſeimh gheibh ſealbh fa ntir,
bid ait an mead na ſith'
13. Chi Dia gu bfuil a lo ag teachd,
14. A ngcloidheamh tharraing luchd an uilc,
Do theilgail ainnis ſíos, is bochd,
15. A ngcloidheamh theid na ncroidhe fein,
17. Oir briſſear gairdein luchd an uilc:
18. Ar laith na nſaoi is fioſrach Dia,
19. Is ann ſa naimſir ghabhuidh olc
Oir gheibheadar an ſáth gu lór
20. Achd ſgrioſſar luchd an uilc gu ler,
Mar ſhaill na nuan thig orra claoi:
'ſ cho díol iad rís ar ais:
22. Lion bheannuigh Dia bid buan 'ſa ntír
23. Gach ceim don' déagh-dhuin' ſdiuiridh Dia
24. Da dtuiteadh ſé, cho leagfar glan;
25. Do bhaghus óg, 'ſa nois an aois,
27. Grad ſeachain olc, is dean an maith;
a naoimh cho treig ſe chaoich;
Sior-choimhdear iad, achd ſgat har ſios
30. Thig beul na nſaoi ar gliocas glan
31. Ta lagh a Dhia gu ceart na chroidh
32. Ta drochdhuin' feitheamh ar an tſaoi
da mhar bhadh, déis gach truaigh.
33. Cho nfhág an Tighearn' é na laimh
Ni fhágar ris é ann a mbéinn
34. Feith thuſ' ar Dhia, is coimhed lúl,
Tra chi tu drochdaoin' ar a ngclaoi
35. An droch-dhuin chunnaic me gu tric
Mar chraoibh bhios fás gu doſrach úr
36. Achd chuaidh ſe thart, is feuch ni raibh;
37. Amhraic is feuch, oir ſith is críoch
39. Slaint' dhaoine ceart o Dhia ata,
an neart re cradh is ſgíos.
Is fuaſgluidh, bhridh a ndochas ann
O Thighearn' ann do chorruidh mhoir
Na dean mo ſmachdughadh gu geúr
Is orm ata do lamh gu trom
3. Ni bfuil eun fhallanachd a mfhéoil
Am' chuamhaibh ni bfuil ſith no ſlaint'
4. Oir chuaidh mo pheacaidh os mo chiond:
5. Do lobli mo chreuchdainn, chinn iad breún
re brón gach lá a m'euil.
7. Mo leaſraidh lán do ghalar ghrann,
8. Taim leon, combruit'; re búireadh goirt
mo neart me dfhág a gcein.
An dtaic re fradharc gheur mo ſhul.
chum uam ar ais, a ncéim.
12. Leag goiſte dhamh luchd iarraidh manam,
Na nlathair ſúd do jarr mo lochd;
13. Achd dhfan, mar dhuine bobhar, mis,
Mar bhalbhan dfhan me fein a mthámh
14. A nſo mar dhuine me nach gcluinn,
15. Dhiot rinn me bun, Dhé, feitheam ort,
16. Oir chum nach biodh ac a • ibhneas orm,
17. Am' fhiaghnais 'ta mo bhrón do ghná,
20. Drong dhiolfas olc arſon an maith,
21. A Thighearna, na tréig me nois,
mo Dhia, fad uam na bi.
22. Dhia, deibhrigh do mo chuidiugh • dh,
os tu mo ſhlaint' a chaoích.
A Dubhras, bheir mo ſhligh fanear,
Teann choimhdim fós le ſréin mo bheul
ar bheith don daoi am chóir.
2. Dfhanas gu toſtach balbh am thamh
on ní ſin fein budh mhaith,
3. Las tine dhamh tra ſmuaintigh me,
4. Dhamh ar mo chrich tóir fios.
Creud tomhas fos mo laithe, a Dhe,
Ga hanbhand me, 'ſga gearr mo ré
5. Feuch rinn tu mar leud bois mo laith,
'S fior dhiomhaineas gach ti gu dearbh
6. A mfioghair bhréig ag ſiobhail fós
Gan fhios cia chruinnigheas fa dheoigh
9. Dfhan balbh, 'ſni dfhoſguil me mo bheul,
os tu ſud fein do nochd.
10. Le beim do laimh do chlaoidheadh me;
tog dhiom do bhuill' a Dhé.
11. Tra ſmachduigheas tu neach ma lochd
Mar ghadmuin bheir tu nuas a dhreach
12. Dhia, eiſd re m'urnaidh is rem' ghlaodh,
rem' dheoir ad' thoſd na bi;
Oir coigreach leat, 'ſ fear cuairt ataim
DHeith me le foighid mhaith ar Dhia
2. Do thog ſe as ſlochd uamhun me,
Ar charruig chomhnurt chuir mo chos.
3. Is chuir ſe óran nuadh am' bheul,
deadh chlú ar nDia gu ré:
Chi moran é, fuidh eagal bid,
4. Beannuight an duine ſin gu dearbh
Cho ghabh ſe ſpéis don' ardcheannach
no dhruing le bréig theid ſaobh.
do chuir tu fein a ngniomh,
Do ſmuainte fós a dtaice rinn,
Cho naireamh neach dhuit iad ar leath:
dan nochd fuinn iad, mo Thriath.
6. Ni tlachd leat jobairt thabhairt dhuít,
Mo chluaſa chlaoich is dfhoſguil thu •
A nrola ghlan do leabhair, Dhe,
8. Do thoil a dheanamh, O mo Dhia,
ſé ſin is tlachd dhamh fein:
Do lagh am' chroidh a ſtigh ata
do chuir me nois a ngceill:
Feuch, 'ſaithnidh dhuit gu maith, a Dhe,
ni choiſg me fein mo bheul.
Do nochd me tfhirinn is do ghean,
• 1. Na cumſa uam do throcair chaomh
• 2. Na huilc do jath me ar gach leth
Mo pheacaidh ghlac ſiad me gu teann
Is lionmhuir iad no folt mo chinn,
bhridh ſin, do lag mo chroidh;
• 3. Dhia, gu ma toil leat furtadhach orm:
• 4. Biodh náir is amhluadh dhoibh le cheil
Le maſladh ruaigfear iad ar ais
• 5. Na naonar, fás, gan áiteach fós
Gu raibh na deir le fanoid riom
Sior-abradh iad ler' dtaigh do ſhlaint,
Dia, gu ma mór a chlu.
17. Achd mis, ge hainnis, bochd ataim,
BEannuight' an ti le tuigſe ghlan
A nló an chruadhaig is a chás
2. Ni dion do is a chonbhail beo,
bheir Dia dho neart gu lor;
A leaptha uile ni tu dho
4. A dubhras, Dhia, dean trocair orm,
Oir pheacaigh me a taghaidh fein
5. Mo naimhde cháinfid me, ag radh,
Ca huair do gheibh ſé bás?
Ca huair do ſgrioſfar as a ainm.
6. Dom' amhrac ma thig ſé a mghóir,
A chroidh' ta torradh uile dho ſtigh,
Ag ſmuaineadh is ag cumadh lochd
Nois ar bheith dho na luigh gu tinn
9. Seadh fós, mo charaid dileas fein
Do chéaluigh m'aran ar mo bhord
10 Achd thuſ' a Dhé, dean trocair orm,
is tog me rís an aird,
11. Trid ſo is fioſrach me gu beachd
Bhridh, buaigh nach tug mo namhaid orm.
Dhé, ann ſgach cúis gu brath.
O aois gu haois gu ſuthain ſein.
MAr thogra na ndamh-feigh gu huiſg'
O Dhia, a ngeall ort fein
2. Ghabh manam tart ar diaidh Dhia,
Ca huair na fhiaghnais thiocfas me,
3. Mo dheoir ſiad 'ſbiagh dhamh lô is aoich,
Le druing do chleachd a radha riom
4. Ar cuimhniughadh dhamh ſo gu leir,
Oir chuaidh me leis a chuideachd mhor
da ngnath dol chum do theach.
Chuaidh leis a chuideachd ſin do bhi
5. O manam! creud far leagadh thu
Is creud fa bfuil tu am thaobh ſtigh
Cuir dochas daingean ann a nDia
Arſon an fhurtachd is an tſlaint'
6. Thuit manam jonnam ſros, a Dhé,
7. Le fuaimneach tfheadan uiſg', a Dhe,
8. Dla maith, ſé dhorduigheas dhamh fein
San aoich a óran bidhidh leam;
9. A deirim, Creud far threagfais me,
Creud as fa bfuilim triall fa bhrón
ceart mar le cloidhimh am' chnamh:
Oir deir ſiad riom, Ca bfuil do Dhia?
11. O manam! creud far leagadh tu
Is creud fa bfuil tu ionnam ſtigh
Cuir dochas ann a nDia do ghna,
Os ſé is ſlainte do mo ghnúis,
O Dhia, cum cothrom riom anois,
2. Creud as far theilgeas meiſe uait,
Creud as far ſhiobhlam déurach truagh
3. Dhia, tfhirinn is do ſholas glan
Ar chlairſigh bhinn do mholfam thu,
O Dhia mo Dhiaſ' gach toiſg.
5. O manam, creud far leagadh tu?
is creud fa bfuíl gan chlos?
Cuir dochas ann a nDia do ghná,
Oir ſé is ſlainte do mo ghnúis,
An allúd mar a dhearnadh tu
2. Led' laimh mar thilgis mach na ſloigh,
Mar rinneas ar a phobal claoi
3. Oir ſealbh ſa ntir ni fuaradar
Ní mo do rin a ngandein fein
Achd do lamh dheas, do ghairdein fos
Is ſolas glan do ghnúis doibh ſud;
O Dhia, os tu mo righ.
5. Dar naimhdibh bheir ſinn leagadh goire
Trid thainmſe ſaltridh ſinn gu lár
6. Oir as mo bhogh cho dean me bun,
7. Achd ſhaor tu fein or naimhdibh ſinn,
8. Uaill feadh an lo ni ſinn a nDia,
9. Achd thilg tu dhiot, is náirigh ſinn:
ni chuaidh tu mach ler ſluagh.
10. On namh achd thug tu teicheadh oirn:
rinn creich dhinn luchd ar fuadh.
11. Mar chaoiribh, thug thu ſinn 'nar biagh
12, An aiſgidh reic do phobul ſein,
13. Gniomh náir', dar comharſnaibh ar ſa •
Is do gach neach ata far cuairt
14. Ameaſg, na ngeint leach le cheil
'Sa meaſg a phobuil ann ſgach áit
15. Ta m'amhluadh is mo mhaſladh geur
Is náire mhor mo ghruaidh, ata
16. Arſon guth ſhir na ſpreigeadh cruaidh
Bhridh fhir na dioghaltuis, is fos
17. So uile ge do thainig orm,
Ni rinn ſinn breug, no briſeadh claon
18. Ni aom ar gcroidhea uait ar ais:
ni chlaon ar gcém od ród.
19. Is ge do phronn tu ſinn gu mion
Ge dfholaigh thu ſinn fós gu tric
20. Ma leig ſinn ainm ar nDia a cuimhn'
Ma ſhín ſinn mach ar lamh do chum
21. Nach rannſuigh Dia ſo mach, ga bfuil
22. Oir ar do ſhon do mharbhthar ſinn
ar feadh an la gu leir:
Mar chaoiribh fos do mheaſfar ſinn
23. O moſguil, creud fan codlann tú?
Na tilgſe ſinne dhiot gu bráth,
24 Creud as fá nfholuigh tu do ghnúis?
Ar namhghar is ar négin mhór
25. Oir chrom ar nanam ſios don ûir
ar ſgá do ghrás, lé clú.
DEagh adhbhar órain naoimh gu fior
Is labhram ar na neithibh ſin
Mar phean a nlaimh an ſgriobhneoir ghléuſd
2. Is maiſigh thu no clann na ndaoin
Ar ſin, thug Dia buan-bheannachd dhuit.
Cuir riot do chloidheamh ar do leas
5. Do ſhoighhe 'taid ro ghéur, is ſaitht'
a ngcroidh gach namh don righ:
Trid ſin an pobal tuitid fúd,
Oſciond do ſheiſcadh chuir do Dhia
Do chuir ſiad aoibhneas ort leo ſud
A bhainriogh ſeaſamh ar do dheis
10. A jnghean, eiſd, is toir fanear
Tigh tathar is do mhuinntir fein
Oir ſé do Thighearn' is do thriath,
Bíd dabine ſaibhir meaſg an tſluaigh
13. Inghean an righ ata ar feadh
a ſtigh ro lán do ghloir:
14. A ngiobuil ghreiſt le ſnathaid fos
bheir ſiad i chum an righ:
15. Do thig ſiad 'ſteach a ngcuirt an righ,
16. Arſon do ſhinnſear bíd do chlann,
17. Tainm ghlormhar do gach linn a thig,
Ar ſin, do bheir a mpobal duit
SE Dia ar tearmunn, is ar treis:
Re carroid is re cruaidh chás fos
2. Ar ſin, dan' áthruight' talamh trom,
Dan' tilgte fós na ſleibhte mór
3. Da rachadh uiſgeach thar a ehéil
Le'n ataireachd; da mbiodh ar crioth •
4. Ta abhann ann, ni baile Dhé
Fior-áite naomh an ti is aírd,
5. Ta Dia na meadhon jnnt' a ſtigh:
Ni Dia a cuidiughadh gu mor,
is ſin gu much do ni.
6. Do ghabh na cinnigh buile bhorb,
Ar cur do Dhia a ghuth amach
7. Ta Dia na nſluagh far linn do ghná,
9. Glan-chlos rinn ſe a ngcrich gach tír,
Se bhriſfeas bogh', is ghearras ſleagh;
10: Bibh ſamhach, 'ſ tuigibh gur me Dia;
Feadh chinneacha; is gheibh me gloir
11. Ta Dia na nſluagh far linn gan cheiſt
Dia Jacob, ſé is tearmunn duinn
Fonn aoibhneach togaibh ſuas dó Dhia,
2. Oir Dia ró ard, is uamhunn é,
3. A mpobul cuiridh ſé fa'r ſmachd,
fa'r gcois na ſloigh gu fior:
4. Ar noighreachd taghaidh ar ar ſon,
5. Chuaidh Dia le gáirthe buadha 'n aird,
6. Sinnibh do Dhia, ſinn moladh, ſinn
8. Ar cathair a naomhthachd ſuighionn ſe;
na righ mór thar gach dream.
Gan cheiſt ſle Dia amháin gach ſgia,
IS mor Jehobha, Dia na mfeart,
A lár ſleibh ghloin a naomhachd fein,
Fa-comhair fos, da taobh ma thuàdh
4. Oir feuch, tra chruinnigh iomdha righ
do chuaidh iad ſeach le chéil
5. Tan chunnaic ſud, ghabh jongnadh iad,
6. Ghlac cagal iad annſin, is pian
le gaoi an ear fa dheoidh.
8. Mar chual, is amhluidh chunnairc ſinn
A mbail' ar nDia; Dia ni gu bráth
9. Ad' theampul ar do chaoimhneas caoimh
10. Mar thainm is amhluidh ſin do chlu
11. Beinn Shion gu ma haoibhin í,
12. Nois ſiobhlaibh Sioin ar gach taobh,
Chum ſin gu gcuirfeadh ſibh a ngceill
14. Oir ſé an Dia ſo fein ar Dia
Sé threoruigheas gu ham ar báis
EIſdibh ris ſo, a ſhluagh gu leir,
2. Is cluinnibh eidir mhór is bheag,
Tra dhiathfas jomam lochd mo ſhál,
6. Na daoine ſin ni dochas mór
7. Ni bféid ein neach ar ghné ar bith
Thoirt eraic ar a ſhon do Dhia
9. Gu mairfeadh ſé gu ſiorraidh beo,
10. Oir chi ſe chean' na daoine glic,
11. Se ſo is ſmuainteadh dhoibh a ſtigh
gu mair' an tigh le glonn,
an ainm toirt ar a mfonn.
12. Gidheadh an duin' an onoir mhoir,
Achd theid ſé thart gan chuimhne air
13. An ſlighe ſud ge gorrach í,
Na firéin glacfuid os a ngceann
Is ſdargaidh fós an dreach 'ſa nuaigh
15. Achd ſaoraidh Dia dhamh manam bochd
Oir gabhaidh ſe me chuige iein
16. A nuair do nithear ſaibhir neach
Sa ntan a chinneas gloir • a theach
17. An tanam oir tra fhágſas é
ni bheir ſe maoin de leis;
'Sa nuair do theid ſe ſios don' uaigh
18. A anam ge do bheannuigh ſé
Smór moladh dhaoine ort gach áit
an maith dhui • fein tra ni.
19. Gu hál a ſhinnſear theid ſe ſiós,
20. An duin' an onoir, is gan tuigſ'
On aird' an ear gu haird an jér
2. As Sioin ard is foirſe mais
3. Thig fós ar nDia, 'ſcho bhi na thoſd,
4. Ar talamh is ar neamha ſhuas
Do thabhairt ar a phobul fein
Rinn cumhnant leam le hiobairt ghlan,
6 A cheartſan nochdfaidh neamh na néul;
Arſon nach tug tu jad gu léir
am fhiaghna • s fein gach ló.
9. Tarbh óg cho ghabhuinn as do thigh,
10. Oir 'ſleam gach ainmhidh béo a ngeoill;
12. Geur ocras da mbiodh orm, no gort
is na bſuil ann le cheil.
13. An ólfuinn fuil na ngabhar uait?
Ort fuaſglam: gloír is bheir tú dhamh
do chuidigh thu le m' neart.
16. Achd ris an droehdhuin' do radh Dia,
Mo ſtatuin nochdadh; no ad' bheul
